photo.description: The Marines lining up before the start of the rededication ceremony at Kansas City, Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: marines soldiers flags rededication kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Marines In A Row

photo.description: American soldiers during World War I were referred to as Doughboys, but why? No one really knows the answer, but here are some of the theories. From Wikipedia: "The origin of the term is unclear. The most commonly held explanation is that it came into use in the Civil War in reference to the dumpling-shaped buttons on the Union soldiers' jackets. Others claim that it goes back to the Mexican-American War of 1846-48, or originated from an early form of the doughnut, called the doughboy. Another explanation of the term stems from the time of the Punitive Expedition against Pancho Villa in 1916, in which the infantry were constantly covered with dust from marching through the dry terrain of northern Mexico, giving them the appearance of unbaked dough. Other explanations point to the use of pipe clay, which looks like dough, to clean infantrymenâ€™s white belts; another is that it is a corruption of "adobe boy" from the adobe bricks used to house infantrymen in the pre-Civil War Southwest; and yet another that it refers to the "soft" condition of the young soldiers, applied by British and French forces in World War I who had already fought nearly four years. None of these theories is definite." Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: doughboy soldier american rifle helmet kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Doughboy InThe Elements

photo.description: This wall shows the different insignias worn by the soldiers. Each symbol designates a different military division. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: insignias patches uniform division infantry rainbow kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Insignias

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. The museum has a large recreation of trench warfare. To see the trench, there are small "head holes" that you stick you head through to see into their world and hear the sounds of war. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: trench sandbags barbedwire soldiers recreation exhibit kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: The Trench

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. Inside the museum, but not in the exhibits, these small interactive windows show photographs of soldiers who served during the war. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: soldiers photographs history interactive kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. A display showcasing jackets and symbols of the war. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.

photo.description: Liberty Memorial in Kansas City. The official national monument to commemorate World War I. Apparently it is also the only national monument created in the Art Deco Style. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. Just after the release of doves, the curtain is parted, and the museum offically opens to the public. At the podium is Kansas City Mayor Kay Barnes. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. During the rededication ceremony, Kansas Governor Kathleen Sebelius spoke about the museum. I thought it was interesting that the governor of Kansas attended this event, even though the museum is in Missouri. Also, Governor Matt Blunt was listed in the program, but did not attend. He was also not mentioned during the ceremony. If he had missed the ceremony due to inclement weather (highly possible) wouldn't he have sent a message to be read in his absence? Interesting... Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: governor sebelius kansas ceremony kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Governor Sebelius

photo.description: This photo was taken just about an hour before the opening of the renovated Liberty Memorial Museum. A giant black curtain was placed over the new entrance for the ceremony. The eyes on the curtain symbolize the purpose of the museum - to allow the visitor to see the war through the soldiers' eyes. Also, the flags of the allied forces were flown (left to right: Great Britian, Belgium, U.S., Italy and France) Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: curtain flags greatbritian belgium italy france tower fountain kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: The Eyes Of War

photo.description: Liberty Memorial Tower, Kansas City. This is the tower dedicated in 1921 after the World War I. Many people and generals gathered around here for the peace after the first massacre swept all around the world. As you all know, peace hadn't last that long after this dedication. PENTAX *istDs, f5.6, 55mm, 1/1500s, ISO200.
photo.tags: wwi war memorial museum kansascity
photo.title: For the Peace of All Mankind

photo.title: Remained...

photo.description: Liberty Memorial Museum, Kansas City. Canister that was used for pigeon messengers during the World War I. Just imagine how many soldiers had been saved through this small packet...and what can I do to save someone else? PENTAX *istDs, 26mm, f4.0, 1/125s, ISO1600.
photo.tags: dof pigeon messenger wwi war memorial kansas museum
photo.title: Messenger

photo.tags: war memorial museum kansascity helmet german wwi
photo.title: Enemy...

photo.description: Liberty Memorial Museum, Kansas City. One of the slides used to train soldiers during the World War I. PENTAX *istDs, f4.0, 24mm, 1/90s, ISO1600.

photo.description: I recently went to the Liberty Memorial here in Kansas City. This is the only monument in the United States dedicated to the memorial of World War 1. I would highly recommend visiting it if you come to Kansas City. Its a beautiful monument and museum. The memorial is currently undergoing some renovations which somewhat limited the shots I could take. This turned out to be kind of nice in this case. The memorial is so large and there are so many angles you can shoot it from sticking to a limited area aloud me to not worry about other possible shots and focus on just this area. I will probably return to the memorial several more times in the future to try some different compositions. This is one of the first shots I took this evening. I was really waiting for the sun to get lower and for the sky to change a little more before starting to shoot but I just loved how the blue and orange/yellow colors compliment each other. The clouds really worked well for this shot as well. I really like how the memorial looks out over the Kansas City sky line.
photo.tags: libertymemorial worldwar1 kansascity monuments worldwarmemorial kansas hdr
photo.title: Liberty Memorial

photo.description: The weather during the Liberty Memorial rededication was COLD. Symbolic of their assistance during the war, the American Red Cross gave out free coffee, hot chocolate and mini cinnamon rolls. Thank you, Red Cross! Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: american redcross free coffee hotchocolate kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: It's FREE

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. As a graphic designer, I wanted to add this photo to show how the museum used type to convey information. It's very legible and well spaced. The way it should be. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: type lettering graphics exhibit kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: French Trench Type

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. A display of a cot, table and stretcher used by the medical personnel during the war. This display is covered in a light fabric. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: cot table stretcher medical exhibit kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Taking Care of the Wounded

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. This photo might look like just a light table, but it's not. It's much more. It's actually a bunch of interactive monitors that you can interact with using laser wands. A must see! Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: interactive table light digital laser animated kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Interactive Table

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. A Biplane flies near the Liberty Memorial Tower during the rededication ceremony. During the ceremony, the plane dropped rose petals on the crowd. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: biplane airplane tower ceremony kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Biplane

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. This photo is of a display of artifacts (like gas masks, shell casings, etc.) that are placed under the floor along with type and covered with glass so you can walk over the top of it. This blurry photo doesn't do it justice. Very cool. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: glass gasmask type lettering shells bullets kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Glass Floor Case

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. Another one of the museums "environments" is this recreation of a bomb crater. The visitor steps into the middle of a giant hole showing the enormity of the destruction. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: crater hole damage mud destruction exhibit kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Crater

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. From the entrance of the museum, you can see through the glass roof up towards the Liberty Tower. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: tower glass ceiling entrance kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Looking Up At The Tower

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. Just inside the museum is a large field of poppies, symbolizing the poppies that grew on the battlefields of Belgium and France throughout the war regardless of the conditions. It is also a reference to the famous poem In Flanders Field. A large glass bridge spans the poppies and leads you into the exhibits. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: poppies bridge glass entrance kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum skylight visitors
photo.title: Field Of Poppies

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. A couple of large cannons inside the new museum. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: cannons displays kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Cannons

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. Once inside the museum, this large room sets the stage for the visitor by showing the conditions in Europe before the war, and the reasons the war happened. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: giant murals beginning introduction kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Beginning of the Museum, Beginning of the War

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. One of the displays on the museum's interactive tables shows posters, photos and artwork of Kansas City during the World War I era. I thought it was cool there was a reference to KC's old Electric Park. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: interactive table photos art electricpark kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: KC During The War

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. War era propaganda posters. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: posters propaganda art design kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: European War Posters

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. The opening wall just inside the museum. This museum was designed by famous museum designer Ralph Appelbaum. He is responsible for the design of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum and for the American Museum of Natural History. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: exhibit kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: The World War

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. One of the signature items of this museum is a giant IMAX-like screen that is about 100 feet wide and helps the visitor experience the war. Just below the screen is a recreation of soldiers slogging through the mud and rubble. This is another example of how my blurry photo does not do this exhibit justice. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: screen horizontheater movie exhibit soldiers mud kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Horizon Theater

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. Looking very similar to the exhibit room at the beginning of the museum, this room looks back at the lessons of the war, and towards the consequences for the future - namely World War II. Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: war exhibit end skyscrapers kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: The End Of War

photo.description: Kansas City Missouri's Liberty Memorial World War I Museum. This is looking throught the glass bridge inside the museum down on to the field of poppies. The bridge is very sturdy, but I felt a little uncomfortable at first walking over this transparent bridge! Visit my website: ChrisM70.com.
photo.tags: bridge glass poppies entrance kansascity missouri libertymemorial nationalworldwarimuseum wwi grandreopening museum
photo.title: Glass Bridge
